learning_objectives: Identify the parts of an electric cell (positive terminal, negative terminal, internal chemicals).
Explain that an electric cell converts chemical energy into electrical energy to produce an electric current.
Demonstrate how connecting a cell to a complete circuit allows a bulb to light up.
Understand the role of the positive and negative terminals in the flow of electric current.
key_concepts: Electric cell as a source of electric current.
Positive and negative terminals of a cell.
Electric current as the flow of charges through a circuit.
Conversion of chemical energy to electrical energy.
variables_to_simulate: Number of cells in series (1 or 2 cells)
user_interactions: Toggle switch to open/close the circuit
Button to flip the cell orientation (swap terminals)
Slider to add/remove a second cell (0 or 1 additional cell)
simulation_logic: Initialize the simulation with a single electric cell, a bulb, and an open circuit.
Display a clear diagram of the cell showing the positive (+) and negative (-) terminals.
When the user closes the circuit (toggle switch), check the cell orientation and bulb condition.
If the circuit is closed and the cell is correctly oriented, the bulb lights up (simulating current flow).
If the user flips the cell orientation, the bulb remains off to show that current cannot flow without proper polarity.
If the user adds a second cell, the bulb glows brighter (increased voltage), but only if the circuit is closed and correctly oriented.
If the user selects a burnt-out bulb, the bulb remains off even if the circuit is closed and correctly oriented.
Provide visual feedback (e.g., arrows showing charge flow) when the circuit is complete and the bulb is working.
mobile_ui_plan: Top section: Title and brief instruction text with an icon.
Middle section: Interactive simulation area with a large, clear diagram of the electric cell, wires, and bulb.
Below the diagram: Toggle switch for the circuit, button to flip cell orientation, slider for adding a second cell, and button to change bulb condition.
Bottom section: Multiple-choice questions with radio buttons and a 'Check Answer' button.
All elements are large and touch-friendly for mobile use.
misconceptions_to_address: Electric cells and batteries are the same thing.
Current flows without a complete circuit.
The orientation of the cell does not matter.
More cells always make the bulb brighter regardless of connection.
text_instructions_for_students: Welcome! In this simulation, you will learn how an electric cell works.
Look at the diagram of the electric cell. Notice the positive (+) and negative (-) terminals.
Use the toggle switch to close the circuit and see what happens to the bulb.
Try flipping the cell orientation and observe the effect.
Add a second cell and see how it changes the brightness of the bulb.
Replace the bulb with a burnt-out one and see what happens.
Answer the questions to check your understanding.
safety_constraints: No high-voltage simulations or dangerous scenarios.
All interactions are virtual and safe for students.
Content is age-appropriate and aligns with CBSE Class 7 curriculum.
